journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part N: Journal of Nanoengineering and Nanosystems

title-group.article-title: Effect of momentum slip on double-diffusive free convective boundary layer flow of a nanofluid past a convectively heated vertical plate

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Engineering Sciences, National University of Science and Technology, Pakistan
2School of Mathematical Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Malaysia

author-notes.corresp: Waqar A Khan, Department of Engineering Sciences, Pakistan Navy Engineering College, Karachi 75350, Pakistan. Email: wkhan_2000@yahoo.com

abstract.p: The Buongiorno and Darcy models have been used to investigate the effects of momentum slip on the double-diffusive free convective flow past a convectively heated vertical plate in a medium saturated with nanofluids. The vertical plate has uniform surface temperature, solutal and nanoparticle concentrations. The governing transport equations are transformed into four nonlinear, coupled similarity equations using similarity transformations developed by scaling group transformation, and are solved numerically to obtain the dimensionless functions in the respective boundary layers and the dimensionless heat and mass transfer rates. The solution depends on various dimensionless numbers, and nanofluid, double-diffusion and slip parameters. The results of the present paper show that the flow velocity, temperature, nanoparticle concentration, reduced local Nusselt and reduced Sherwood numbers are strongly influenced by the hydrodynamic slip parameter.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the rapid advances in nanofluids, many inexpensive combinations of nanoparticles and base fluids are now available. These include nanoparticles of aluminum, copper, gold, iron and titanium or their oxides. The base fluids used are usually water, ethylene glycol, oil and toluene. Experimental investigations1–7 show that the thermal conductivity of the base fluid can be enhanced by 10–50% by the inclusion of a small volumetric fraction of nanoparticles (usually less than 5%). This enhancement in the thermal conductivity of nanofluids makes them attractive for use in many applications such as advanced nuclear systems8 and cylindrical heat pipes.9 Detailed reviews of the heat transfer characteristics of nanofluids can be found in the literature.10–14 Buongiorno15 proposed an analytical model for convective transport in nanofluids that takes into account the Brownian diffusion and thermophoresis, and concluded that the increase in the heat transfer coefficient was due to a significant decrease in the viscosity of the fluid caused by the large temperature variations in the boundary layers.

Natural convective boundary layer flow of a nanofluid past a vertical plate under different boundary conditions has been investigated by a number of researchers.16–23 Kuznetsov and Nield16 extended the classical problem of natural convection of a regular fluid over an isothermal vertical plate to the flow of a nanofluid. Later, the same authors extended the study to a nanofluid saturated porous medium,17 extending the well-known Cheng–Minkowycz problem18 to a nanofluid. The Buongiorno model15 has also been used by Khan and Pop19 to study the boundary layer flow of a nanofluid past a stretching sheet, and by Khan and Aziz20 to investigate the boundary layer flow of a nanofluid past a vertical surface with a constant heat flux. The lacuna between the work of Kuznetsov and Nield16 and Khan and Aziz20 has been recently covered by Aziz and Khan,21 who employed a thermal convective boundary condition to study natural convection in a nanofluid past a vertical surface.

Double-diffusive convection could be found in many fields, including chemical engineering, solid-state physics, oceanography, geophysics and so on. A detailed review of this topic is given by Pop and Ingham.22 The double-diffusive nanofluid convection in porous media has been investigated by Kuznetsov and Nield,23,24 They employed the Buongiorno model for the nanofluid and the Darcy model for the porous medium. They obtained a similar solution based on conventional no-slip boundary condition. In another paper, the same authors extended the Cheng–Minkowycz problem for the double-diffusive natural convective boundary layer flow of a nanofluid in a porous medium.25 Later on, Khan and Aziz26 employed the same idea to study the double-diffusive natural convection from a vertical plate under prescribed surface heat, solutal and nanoparticle fluxes.

The above literature survey reveals that no study has been conducted to investigate the effects of momentum slip on double-diffusive free convection past a convectively-heated vertical plate. The fluids exhibiting momentum slip have technological applications, such as in the polishing of artificial heart valves and internal cavities. The objectives of this study are to investigate the effects of momentum slip and convective heat transfer parameters on the dimensionless velocity, temperature, solutal and nanoparticle concentrations, heat and mass transfer rates for water-based nanofluids. To the best of our knowledge, the results of this paper are new and they have not been published before.

sec.title: The group-theoretic method approach
sec.p: The transport equations (9)–(13) are highly coupled nonlinear boundary value problems. A closed-form analytical solution of these equations does not exist. Numerical solutions of these equations are complicated and computationally expensive. In recent years similarity solutions have proved to be an efficient method for solving various transport problems. In this section we will show how scaling group transformation combines two independent variables (x, y) into a single independent variable (η) and reduces the governing partial differential equations to corresponding ordinary differential equations. For this purpose we consider the following one-parameter scaling group of transformation

where ε (parameter of the group) and
α
i
( i = 1 , 2 , … , 8 )

sec.title: Numerical solution
sec.p:
Equations. (20)–(23), subject to the boundary conditions of equation (24), were solved numerically using a fourth–fifth order Runge-Kutta–Fehlberg fourth–fifth order numerical method with a shooting technique. The asymptotic boundary conditions given by equation (24) were replaced by a finite value of 11 for the similarity variable,
η
max
, as follows

The choice of
η
max
= 11
ensured that all numerical solutions approached the asymptotic values correctly. This is an important point that is often overlooked in publications on boundary layer flows. In a paper devoted exclusively to the appraisal of published results in boundary layer flows, Pantokratoras33 found that many published results on boundary layer flows are erroneous because the graphs for the velocity and temperature distributions in the boundary layers do not approach the correct values asymptotically. All the errors were the consequence of using smaller values of η to represent the boundary condition at
η → ∞ .
Numerical computations were done for

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The effects of different parameters on the double-diffusive natural convective boundary-layer flow of a nanofluid past a vertical isothermal plate have been studied by Kuznetsov and Nield23,24 and Khan and Aziz.26 In this study, we investigated the effects of hydrodynamic slip on dimensionless functions, parameters and the physical quantities of interest. The results of the reduced Nusselt number
− θ ′ ( 0 )
is compared with Kuznetsov and Nield23 for a special case which is shown in Table 1 and found to be in good agreement. This shows the validity of our numerical results for other cases. Figure 2 shows the effect of momentum slip on various dimensionless functions for mono-diffusive and double-diffusive water-based nanofluids. It is observed that the momentum slip reduces the boundary layer thickness of each dimensionless function for both mono-diffusive and double-diffusive water-based nanofluids. A comparison between the boundary layers shows that the thermal and the solutal concentration boundary layers are of comparable thickness, but the nanoparticle concentration layer is much thinner. Effects of momentum slip on the dimensionless velocity are illustrated in Figure 3 for two different values of Prandtl numbers. The maximum velocity within the boundary layer increases with an increase in the partial slip for both mono-diffusive and double-diffusive water-based nanofluids. A comparison between mono-diffusive and double-diffusive water-based nanofluids shows that the dimensionless velocity at the surface is greater for the double-diffusive water-based nanofluids. This is due to the increase in the double diffusive buoyancy and modified Dufour parameters. Note that the maximum velocity within the boundary layer also increases with an increase in Prandtl number. The effect of momentum slip on the dimensionless temperature is depicted in Figure 4(a) for mono-diffusive and in Figure 4(b) for double-diffusive water-based nanofluids for different values of Biot numbers. In both cases, the dimensionless temperature decreases with an increase in Biot number. The effect of momentum slip on the dimensionless temperature within the thermal boundary layer is not dominant, and the thermal boundary layer thickness remains the same in both cases. The same effect of momentum slip on the dimensionless solutal concentration for mono- and double-diffusive water-based nanofluids is shown in Figure 5(a) and (b) for different values of Lewis number. However, the dimensionless solutal concentration decreases with an increase in Lewis number, and as a result the solutal concentration boundary layer thickness decreases and the rate of mass transfer increases. Unlike the dimensionless temperature and the dimensionless solutal concentration, the dimensionless nanoparticle concentration is much more effected by the momentum slip. This is shown in Figure 6(a) for mono-diffusive and in Figure 6(b) for double-diffusive water-based nanofluids. In both cases, the dimensionless nanoparticle concentration decreases with an increase in the nanofluid Lewis number and the momentum slip. It is also noted that the double-diffusive parameters tend to decrease the nanoparticle concentration boundary layer thickness. The variation of reduced local Nusselt and Sherwood numbers with double-diffusive buoyancy and modified Dufour parameters is shown in Figures 7–9 for different Biot and Lewis numbers. The reduced local Nusselt numbers are found to increase with double-diffusive buoyancy parameter (Figure 7(a)) but decrease with modified Dufour parameter (Figure 7(b)). In both cases, they increase with both Bio numbers and momentum slip parameter. The present predictions can be qualitatively compared (when a = 0) with the predictions from the following correlation of Kuznetsov and Nield23 for a vertical surface with constant temperature, constant solutal concentration and constant nanoparticle concentration at the surface

sec.p: Equation (32) also shows that the reduced Nusselt number decreases as Nr, Nb and Nt increase.

Figure 8(a) and (b) shows the variation of reduced local Sherwood numbers with double-diffusive buoyancy and modified Dufour parameters for different values Lewis number and momentum slip parameter. It can be seen that the reduced local Sherwood numbers increase with Lewis numbers, partial slip, double-diffusive buoyancy and modified Dufour parameters. The presence of nanoparticles enhances the Sherwood number because of the contributions of the Brownian motion, thermophoresis and the buoyant motion prompted by the difference in the densities of nanoparticles and the base fluid. The same behaviour of reduced nanofluid Sherwood numbers is shown in Figure 9 for double-diffusive buoyancy and modified Dufour parameters. The nanoparticle Sherwood numbers plotted in Figure 9(a) and 9(b) reveal that the transport of nanoparticles is largely dictated by the double-diffusive process. It is interesting to note that the Brownian motion, thermophoresis and the buoyant motion prompted by the difference in the densities of nanoparticles and the base fluid have hardly any effect on the nanoparticle Sherwood number when double-diffusion occurs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, the effects of momentum slip on double-diffusive free convective boundary layer flow of a nanofluid past a convectively heated vertical plate are investigated numerically. The Buongiorno and Darcy models are used in the transport equations, and similarity solutions are obtained via a scaling group of transformations. The main conclusions emerging from this study are as follows.

list-item.p: For both mono and double diffusions in nanofluids, the boundary layer thicknesses of all dimensionless functions decrease with an increase in momentum slip.
The dimensionless velocity at the surface and within the boundary layer increases with momentum slip for both mono- and double-diffusion processes in a nanofluid.
The dimensionless nanoparticle concentration decreases with an increase in momentum slip for both mono- and double-diffusions in nanofluids.
The reduced local Nusselt, solutal and nanofluid Sherwood numbers increase with momentum slip parameter.
